<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 96, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the exact coordinates of the points on the curve \(y = \frac{x^2}{1 - 3x}\) at which the gradient of the tangent is equal to 8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
On an Argand diagram, shade the region whose points represent complex numbers \(z\) satisfying the inequalities \(|z - 2\mathrm{i}| \leqslant |z + 2 - \mathrm{i}|\) and \(0 \leqslant \arg (z + 1) \leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 88, 621, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 405, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are related by the equation \(y = ab^{x}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. The diagram shows the result of plotting \(\ln y\) against \(x\) for two pairs of values of \(x\) and \(y\). The coordinates of these points are (1, 3.7) and (2.2, 6.46).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 467, 514, 486]]<|/det|>
Use this information to find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 467, 920, 486]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 245, 92]]<|/det|>
Given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 92, 712, 116]]<|/det|>
\[\sin (x + \frac{1}{6}\pi) - \sin (x - \frac{1}{6}\pi) = \cos (x + \frac{1}{3}\pi) - \cos (x - \frac{1}{3}\pi),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 117, 384, 136]]<|/det|>
find the exact value of \(\tan x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 494, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact roots of the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 100, 710, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\sin (x + \frac{1}{6}\pi) - \sin (x - \frac{1}{6}\pi) = \cos (x + \frac{1}{3}\pi) - \cos (x - \frac{1}{3}\pi)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 128, 277, 147]]<|/det|>
for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 544, 92]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(\theta\) satisfy the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 100, 574, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{x}{\tan \theta}\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}\theta} = x^{2} + 3.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 383, 156]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(x = 1\) when \(\theta = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 720, 187]]<|/det|>
Solve the differential equation, obtaining an expression for \(x^{2}\) in terms of \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 650, 92]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 98, 546, 118]]<|/det|>
\[\sqrt{x} = \mathrm{e}^{x} - 3\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 127, 304, 144]]<|/det|>
has only one root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 148, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 540, 599, 559]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that this root lies between 1 and 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 670, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that, if a sequence of values given by the iterative formula

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 98, 576, 122]]<|/det|>
\[x_{n + 1} = \ln \left(3 + \sqrt{x_n}\right)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 127, 648, 146]]<|/det|>
converges, then it converges to the root of the equation in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 146]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 186, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 400, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula to calculate the root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(x = \sqrt{u}\), or otherwise, find by integration the exact area of the shaded region bounded by the curve, the \(x\)-axis and the line \(x = 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence obtain the expansion of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) in ascending powers of \(x\), up to and including the term in \(x^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 756, 186, 775]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 756, 680, 775]]<|/det|>
State the set of values of \(x\) for which the expansion in (b) is valid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 757, 920, 776]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 85, 712, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(OABCDEFG\) is a cuboid in which \(OA = 3\) units, \(OC = 2\) units and \(OD = 2\) units. Unit vectors \(\mathbf{i}\), \(\mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\) are parallel to \(OA\), \(OD\) and \(OC\) respectively. \(M\) is the midpoint of \(EF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 146, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 398, 380]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 504, 415, 523]]<|/det|>
The position vector of \(P\) is \(\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 146, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 535, 339, 553]]<|/det|>
Calculate angle \(PAM\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 853, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the exact length of the perpendicular from \(P\) to the line passing through \(O\) and \(M\). [5]
